subSubSection.paragraph:
Typhlops lestradei Witte, 1933a
, Rev. Zool. Bot. Afr., 23(2): 207, figs. 1–3. Type locality: “Rubengera, Ruanda ” [= east of Lake Kivu near Kibuye, Rwanda ] ( 2.06°S , 29.35°E , elevation 1500 m ), holotype MRAC 7758, collected by F. Lestrade, 1931; Witte, 1941: 169 ; Roux-Estève, 1975b: 56 .

Typhlops blandfordi lestradei —
Cundall & Irish, 2008: 599
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. Snout rounded, prominent. Rostral oval dorsally with rounded posterior border, narrow ventrally; frontal subhexagonal; supraocular transverse, its lateral apex between preocular and ocular; eye visible anterior to or beneath posterior edge of preocular; nasal sulcus arising from first labial; SIP usually T-II-P (N2, N2/P, O, O), but frequently T-X (P) in an area centred on the Virunga volcanoes; MSR 24–36, reduction A/B +2 to 2, B/C 2–6; MD 350–578 (mean 424.8, n = 136); vertebrae 206–246 (mean 225.9, n = 96); MD/V ratio 1.63–2.21 (mean 1.87, n = 96); L/D ratio 26–60 (mean 37.2, n = 182). Scales dark brown, uniform or paler basally and laterally. Specimens from forest usually lack ventral pigment, those from savanna pigmented ventrally. Largest specimen (MRAC 4024—Lulenga, Kivu, DRC ) has a total length of 660 mm .
Distribution. Cameroon south to Angola , east through the Democratic Republic of the Congo to Uganda , Kenya , northwest Tanzania and northeast Zambia , 675–2075 m ( Fig. 12 ).
